Executive Summary:
Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
The R.E. Badger Filtration Plant emergency response plan is designed to provide the following:
1.  To protect the lives of plant personnel and the constituents within the zone of influence.
2.  For the purpose of mitigating personal injury.
3.  To minimize damage to property and the environment.

All REB personnel actively participate with the safety training and planning for the facility.  The
REB safety plan provides the personnel organization and notification needed to effectively attend
to chlorine and ammonia release issues.  Emergency response plan identifies health hazards and
mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively should an emergency
situation arise.  The plan is a living document that is to be updated should there be any change in
process or procedures.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

Location of the RE Badger Filtration Plant is 18535 Aliso Canyon Road in Rancho Santa Fe,
California, 92067  RE Badger Filtration Plant's initial start-up occurred in 1970.  Chlorine feed
system consists of one-ton containers which are the storage vessels for chlorine.  Chlorine gas is
drawn from a maximum of three tanks at a time through a vacuum regulator to the Chlorinators. 
Still under vacuum from the Chlorinators, the gas is drawn to injectors and mixed with water for
distribution through-out the treatment plant.  Maximum chlorine stored at facility is 18 one-ton
cylinders for a total of 36,000 pounds.

Practices and procedures proper chlorine handling were obtained from the Chlorine Institute
Manual for the Safe Handling of Chlorine.  In addition to plant safety program for the handling
of chlorine, there are chlorine gas detectors in the chlorine storage and feeding rooms that detect

Five Year Accident History

There have been no release of chlorine at this facility in the past 5 years.

Emergency Response Program

An emergency response plan is presently in effect at the RE Badger facility.  The purpose of the
emergency response plan was to aid in reaching the following objectives:
1.  To help save lives.
2.  Prevent and minimize accidents and injuries.
3.  Safeguard the environment.
4.  Safeguard private and public property.

RE Badger's safety committee consists of all plant personnel who are also the designated
emergency responders and coordinators.  The emergency response plan provides the response
organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and
mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations
that may arise at the RE Badger Treatment Plant.  The emergency response plan is reviewed
annually.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Startup of the chlorine feed system took place in 1970.  The process is located at 18535 Aliso
Canyon Road, Rancho Santa Fe, California, 92067.  The chlorine system con

sists of chlorine
one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is drawn from a maximum of
three tanks at a time through a vacuum regulator to the Chlorinators.  While still under vacuum
from the Chlorinators, it is drawn to injectors and mixed with water from the treatment plant. 
The maximum chlorine that can be stored on site is 36,000 pounds.

Hazard Assessment Summary

Scenario Description: Release of the maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored in a
vessel-6,000 pounds (due to a maximum of three one-ton containers connected to a manifold at
any given time) in 10 minutes.  The tanks are stored enclosed in a building, therefore, passive
mitigation measures were used.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5
meters/second wind speed, and F stability.  Reference tables from the EPA's RMP Offsite
Consequence Analysis Guidance for Treatment Plants, along with the SLAB modeling program
were used.

Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 1.9 miles, based on EPA's RMP Guidance for Treatment Plants.

Alternative Release Result Summary

Scenario Description: A release of chlorine gas from a 1/4 inch diameter leak.  The release rate of
chlorine due to the pressure of the tank is 10.1 pounds per minute.  However, active and passive
mitigation measures were incorporated since a scrubbers system is designed to pull contaminated
chlorine gas from the room to be neutralized.  Consequently, the release rate after these measures
was calculated to be 3.2 pounds per minute.  The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters
per second wind speed, and D stability.  Reference tables from EPA Guidance Documents as
well as the SLAB modeling program were used.

Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 0.1 miles, based on EPA's RMP Guidance for Water Treatment
Plants.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The RE Badger Treatment Plant has a Process Safety Management program in place to manage
the handling of chlorine.  In add

ition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are
utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined
by the Chlorine Institute.  In addition to the Management Program, there are two chlorine
detectors in the chlorine storage room and one detector chlorinator room that are set to alarm at 1
ppm and will activate visual as well as audible alarms.  The chlorine scrubber system is also
automatically activated should the chlorine residual reach 15 ppm.

Five Year Accident History

The RE Badger Treatment Plant has had no reportable release of chlorine in the past five years.
